channel.title: Monologue Blog
channel.description: Mainly markets but a smattering of other stuff

item.title: Another week bites the dust with markets grinding higher
item.description:
FAANG Weighting

I saw this neat chart on the Daily Shot (cheapskate edition):

Of course, history doesn’t repeat, or even rhyme, as stonks only go up nowadays.

item.title: Opaque business models
item.description:
What links the FAANG to RobinHood and Tesla?

This article explains how RobinHood is able to offer retail investors commission-free stock trading. This article goes a bit further in suggesting that RobinHood is not really in the business of stealing from the rich to give to the poor, at least …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Schrodinger cat bounce
item.description:
Open

Equities generally up, e.g. NDX futures up 1.4%. How long this will last … Bonds flat: we are in a fairly torrid possibly-starting bear market in equities and bonds are bouncing around as though there is nothing happening. I can’t help thinking this is bearish for bonds …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Velocity of money taking a dive, same as markets
item.description:
Velocity Drops Precipitously

The mysterious “velocity of money” is just GDP divided by the amount of money, in consistent units. The following is created by looking at GDP and M2 (in real dollars). Velocity takes a dive before (and early during) recessions. Maybe this time will be different.

Markets today …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Sleepy Markets on Labour Day
item.description:
Muted start to day

After the fireworks last week, nothing seems to be stirring. Gilt yields are up a bit, the FTSE ($Z) is up 1.5% currently, with average volume. $ESTX50 too. Soybean futures are up. Precious metals seem to be down. Oil is down. The dollar is up …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: So, it was Softbank all along!
item.description:
FAANG Stocks pumped by OTM Calls bought by Softbank!!

Background: sorry, it’s ZeroHedge again. Not reliable as a source, so caveat lector.

There is a constellation of things happening here:

  • retail investors suddenly discovering they can buy calls as lottery tickets that pay out surprisingly often,
  • FAANG stocks where …

item.title: Week ends on a down note?
item.description:
UK Leasehold

Another story about how developers are inserting unfair clauses in leasehold contracts. There are a lot of these. The government is consulting on the issue. The current situation is unacceptable, in my opinion. The relationship between Persimmon and the average first time buyer is very asymmetrical. At the …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Another day in paradise
item.description:
Inflation

John Plender argues that central bank action will make treasuries and gilts (so called “safe assets”) less safe, in that it will increase the correlation of their prices with those of corresponding equities. It’s not Plender’s finest work, but it shows how inflation fears are being reported …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Are we finally seeing monetary conditions ease?
item.description:
Real rates are dropping fast

I finally got around to creating a FRED chart which combines two series. I could probably do it better, but I’m pleased with the result. This is for the US, but global monetary conditions are usually closely correlated (proof?).

What is interesting is that …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Pausing for Breath after a record month-long rally?
item.description:
New Month, New Quarter

Well, August finished up as the best month for the stock market in decades. Why, I have no idea, except “Stocks only go up!” (for those whose memories don’t go back to March).

To start, things are quiet, except I noticed:

  • long Treasury bond futures …

item.title: Late Summer Bank Holiday 2020 Edition
item.description:
Honk Kong not so fragrant real estate market

Central HK office space is getting cheaper. It’s hardly a surprise that this is happening, although maybe it is a surprise that it’s happening so late. I don’t follow this market, although I am vaguely aware that the HK …

item.title: Something ain’t right with the market
item.description:
Inflation expectation out of line with nominal yields

This is from the Market Ear. It shows how the TIPs market has different expectations of future inflation than the Treasury bond/note market. My money would be on the breakevens being right, if I had any.

Wrap

Seems as though terrible …

item.title: A crack in the edifice of the scientific publishing business model
item.description:
Is Alexandra Elbakyan the Dell Glover of the science publishing industry?

Science’s pirate queen, Alexandra Elbakyan is threatening to be the Napster of science publishing. As others have observed, it’s bizarre that the World Wide Web, which was invented to share scientific journal articles freely and easily isn …

item.title: Weekend roundup, 29th Aug 2020
item.description:
Margin Debt is picking up

This is bullish.

Also put-call ratio for NDX at all time low: very bullish.

Spending on services is faltering

Wolf Street points this out. This is bearish (but may not alter the direction of travel). “Services” is such a mis-mash category: I always used to …

item.title: Towards the fully automated company
item.description:
Stock Market Warns Workers That They’re The Problem For Business

This is almost like a headline from The Onion, but actually is a deadly serious piece of research from a highly rated (by me) analyst. Clearly, humans are expensive, unreliable and occasionally dishonest, but only now have we been …

item.title: Market Notes, 27th August 2020
item.description:
Jackson Hole

It came as a surprise to nobody who is even vaguely aware of what Jackson Hole is (apart from a holiday resort) that J Powell is going to allow inflation to run hot and put more emphasis on jobs than price stability. There was quite a bit of …

item.title: Stormy Weather, calm markets
item.description:
Morning comment

Storm Laura is due to hit the southern US states any moment now, AFAICT.

Ant Group, a bit of Alibaba, is trying to get an IPO away in HK and Shanghai. Well, I always think that sellers know more than (potential) buyers in a situation like this, and …

item.title: Inflation expectations and equity market valuations
item.description:
Why are equities so expensive?

Well, it’s the Fed, isn’t it? Maybe, but Robin Wigglesworth gives a slightly more nuanced answer.

This is another forward rate prediction, which shows much the same thing, except there is definitely an uptick at the tail end. Maybe we are seeing the …

item.title: Another episode in the tale of the ancient blogger
item.description:
This market is enough to drive traders to drink

Well, you’d have thought so, but actually not so much. Personally, I think that the world is ready for an alcohol-like drug which doesn’t cause all the health downside of alcohol. This might be what the future tastes like …

item.title: google cloud shell
item.description:
Google Cloud Computing

I like to drop into a shell from time to time. Like the old hacker I am, for minor edits I find nothing more convenient that vi (pax Stallman). I don’t necessarily want to log a PC around with me wherever I go, so I wondered …

item.title: Market Notes, 2020-08-22 12:17
item.description:
It’s Saturday!

The markets were closed today. It’s been a rough week. My evening read today is “The Mind of Wall Street”. Unusually (for me), it’s hardcopy (but not hardback). If you’re local (well, say UK) and you’d like to read it drop me a …

item.title: Market Notes, 21th August 2020
item.description:
Morning

All quiet on the eastern front. All professional investors getting nervous, while the Robinhood crowd count their winnings: A random example.

Fleck thinks that yield curve control is coming, even though the Fed says its not (it has form). He seems to think the dollar has gone down too …

item.title: Market Notes, 20th August 2020
item.description:
Wrap

Risk off, although equities seem to bounce back after hours. Dollar and bonds seem to be rallying: maybe things have been overdone. Precious metals up a bit, but I’m getting nervous about all inflation trades, given that it’s not clear if the Fed can keep creating money …

item.title: Market Notes, 19th August 2020
item.description:
Morning in Europe

Everything quiet as the grave. The SPX breaking through its ATH yesterday was met with a shrug, with everything slightly down, except the FTSE, which was down 1%. That is except Borsa Istanbul, which was up 0.6%, in TRY terms. In EUR terms, not so much …

item.title: Market Notes, 18th August 2020
item.description:
Leverage

You can get contradictory views on almost every aspect of investing. For every willing seller, there has to be a willing buyer.

I liked this from Stanley Druckenmiller, a ‘guru’:

[In March 2008.] I learned a lot at Soros, but not what I thought I would learn. I did …

item.title: Market Notes, 17th August 2020
item.description:
Market action

Seems like the main thing happening today is that the dollar is starting to feel the impact of central bank money printing. Commodities are up, across the board, equities are up (well, it would take a huge meteor strike on NYC to affect that), and bonds are up …

item.title: Text templating using Mustache on Windows
item.description:
The problem

I want to generate a series of text files from a template. I was thinking about using the C preprocessor, cpp. The advantage is that I have used it for years, the disadvantage is that it is specifically written to pre-process C code and is not really general …

item.title: Market Notes, 15th August 2020
item.description:
Krushner and Kodak

You’ve probably heard about how Kodak came to be loaned an extraordinary amount of money to make a drug to tread Covid-19 that nobody thinks works with the result that insiders may become obscenely rich. So far, so well-known. What I had not realized previously was …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Market Notes, 14th August 2020
item.description:
Morning

I just stumbled on The Cow Guy. Crazy suit, crazy guy, but he talked a lot of sense on corn. The news was bad, but the price rallied. As he explained, this is what happens. How long it continues, nobody knows, though, so be careful!

August VIX future ticks …

item.title: Market Notes, 13th August 2020
item.description:
Fiscal Dominance

We are starting to hear more about the concept of fiscal dominance — here and here as well as MMT. Various central bankers for years have been pleading with governments to shoulder more of the burden of getting inflation to go up. Well, now it seems they are getting …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Market Notes, 12th August 2020
item.description:
Morning Call

UK GDP headed down by more than 20% in the quarter but the FTSE goes up. Well, both entirely predictable, but still, in a way, shocking.

Joe Biden (or his minders) announce that it’s Kamala Harris, to just about nobody’s surprise. I guess this probably increases …

item.title: Market Notes, 11th August 2020
item.description:
Inflation: the bear case

Although everyone and his pet monkey is writing about how inflation is around the corner, we haven’t seen it yet, and most of them have been saying that for years anyway. This article, by Michael Strobaek, global chief investment officer at Credit Suisse, argues that …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Market Notes, 10th August 2020
item.description:
Extend and Pretend goes wild

If you reclassify debt enough, it never goes bad. So creditors never have to worry … do they? The funny thing is that credit card debt went right down, which probably mainly just reflects a crash in consumer spending. When Milton Friedman was in his prime …

item.title: Market Notes, 8th August 2020
item.description:
All day

It’s Saturday. I didn’t pay attention to markets today. There weren’t any open. I did read a few articles in the FT saying that inflation was coming, but that buying gold is an unreliable way of profiting from that. I also read one saying that …

item.title: Market Notes, 7th August 2020
item.description:
Morning call

The markets are mainly dead, with a couple of exceptions:

  • Silver has caught fire, overtaking gold in percentage increase terms,
  • The Turkish Lira seems in deep trouble.

I see a lot of press coverage of gold (and a bit of silver) and the inevitable return to discussion of …

item.title: Market Notes, 6th August 2020
item.description:
Market notes

Risk on day, which really means currency debasement day. I didn’t check every asset class, but commodities generally up. Bonds and equities pretty flat. Things seem dangerously quiet, but we are in the dog days of summer.

Trading ideas

David Einhorn, who is very sceptical about $TSLA …

item.title: Market Notes, 5th August 2020
item.description:
Don’t Fight the Fed

Kuppy writes that it’s pointless going short in these markets. This is more or less the summary of a series of podcasts with Grant Williams, Bill Fleckenstein and others. They are all fantastic, but to really have your mind blown, listen to this one …

item.title: Market Notes, 4th August 2020
item.description:
Markets today

Very slightly risk on. Dollar down a tiny amount, after a strong rally over the last few days. Commodities generally up, incl. metals and the oil complex, although softs down. Yields down a tad. Nothing dramatic. The 10-2 curve continues to flatten. Equities up a bit.

News: Tiktok …

item.title: Market Notes, 3rd August 2020
item.description:
The markets today

The general tone seems to be risk on: steeping yield curve, miners down, gold flat, equities up. No very dramatic moves, although SPX is very close to breaching its high for the year, which was (surely) its all time high. Even European bank stocks are rallying, in …

item.description:
I can’t come close to Doug Noland’s CBB depth of coverage of markets.

Credit Bubble Bulletin Summary

I urge you to sign up to this newsletter/blog. It’s free and wonderful. creditbubblebulletin.blogspot.com. It’s worth the price of a Bloomberg.

The S …

item.title: Market Notes, 31st July 2020
item.description:
Morning thoughts

It’s oppressively hot in the UK: not something I often say. The main driver of all price moves today is the dollar, which continues to sag. DX is down 0.46%, which is pushing all other prices up, at least in commodities. Equities are getting a boost …

item.title: Market Notes, 30th July 2020
item.description:
Morning thoughts

TL;DR: none. DXY short looks a bit over extended. DX future seems to be going up today. Probably a reversal, but I can understand the bull thesis. As DX rises, commodity prices fall, in unison. This seems to have happened today, including precious metals. This post from …

item.title: Market Notes, 29th July 2020
item.description:
Morning notes

Gold, silver, copper all flat. Lumber futures (LB) are having a terrific run up. I think this is definitely an inflation signal. Faint stirrings of a yield curve steepening in Treasuries (I live in hope!). The downtrend in China equities looking increasingly established. I’ve been bearish about …
item.dc:creator: me

item.title: Market Notes, 28th July 2020
item.description:
Close Summary

I was too busy to pay much attention to markets today. There were no dramatic moves. US stocks a bit soggy at the close. The VIX was up a bit, at 25.75 (the future). Twitter saying that the Plunge Protection Team had been deployed. Various news about …

item.description:
Markets as good as gold (and silver)

item.title: Kelly Criterion Revisited
item.description:
Recap

The Kelly Criterion tells you how much of your capital you should risk on a single bet, e.g. on a horse in a race. Kelly, in his original paper, contrived a rather odd situation where you actually have an “edge,” i.e. the expected payoff of your bet …

item.title: Market Notes, 25th July 2020
item.description:
I am not on holiday, but I wanted a weekend off.

If you want to know what’s been happening, I recommend the Credit Bubble Bulletin’s weekly roundup. It suggests that the biggest news is a continuing deterioration in the relationship between the US and China. I think that …

item.title: Market Notes, 24th July 2020
item.description:
We have a problem, Houston

The Chinese have reacted to the closing of the Chinese consulate in Houston by expelling the Americans in the US consultate in Chengdu. This was not great for risk assets overnight. NG is on a tear: still going up.

Lies, damn lies, statistics and unemployment …

item.title: Market Notes, 23rd July 2020
item.description:
Morning

Mildly risk-on. Dollar weaker. Lots of articles talking about negative interest rates (US), precious metals breaking higher (especially silver). Global equities generally higher, but Far East looks precarious. I understand the arguments that the Fed cannot let the long end of the curve get out of control, but I …

item.description:
Opening buzz

Risk off today: gold up, bonds up, equities down, VIX up. Dollar ($DX) up, especially against emerging market currencies.

Bailout money goes to shareholders and creditors of already insolvent company

Well, who would have guessed that might happen? Here are the gory details.

In …

item.title: Market Notes, 21st July 2020
item.description:
Is the $TSLA stockprice a bubble?

Well, probably, but this has been true repeatedly in the past year or so. Nobody I follow predicts anything but $TSLA becoming $TSLAQ, but this is because I’m human and I like to follow people who confirm my priors.

In other news

Forex …

item.title: Market Notes, 20th July 2020
item.description:
All day

AGG is trading at a 60-day vol of 4.4%. Long calls, anyone?

. It’s not tumbling, but it’s on a trend. This implies yield curve steepening. One to keep watching, rather than one to act on right away, I think.

Wrap

Crazy risk on day today …

item.title: Weekly Wrap 18th July 2020
item.description:
Economic news

US mortgage arrears are spiking. Not really a surprise, but Wolf gives the details. Headlines can be misleading, as mortgages in forebearance are not counted.

Silver seems to be breaking out. I don’t really know why, but it seems a thing. I somehow feel it’s linked …

item.title: Market Notes, 17th July 2020
item.description:
Markets since Wed

I was away the last few days. I didn’t make any notes, but the market doesn’t seem to have done much. There are more hopes of a vaccine. $MRNA is doing well, but there seem to be multiple companies which are close.

$NFLX crashed on …

item.title: Market Notes, 14th July 2020
item.description:
Morning

After the puke yesterday, markets are fairly muted. Equities are down ~1% in Europe. The $ES_F is actually up 40bp. Commods are generally down, incl. copper & gold. The 10year note has barely budged. It’s almost as if the Fed spending $4 trillion bonds has hampered price discovery for …

item.title: Market Notes, 13th July 2020
item.description:
Morning

Risk on (as usual). Bonds almost flat. Commods up generally, apart from the crude complex. Copper jumps because of some trouble in Chile. Equities up, vaccine rumours. Dollar flat. It’s Monday. Nothing will be clear until the US opens.

Wrap

Huge puke in the main equity indexes late …

item.description:
All Day

item.description:
Morning report

Everything seems pretty flat. Nasdaq & Apple continue to defy gravity. International equities have quite a dispersion. Generally China up, rest of Asia down, Europe down. SPX futures down a tiny bit, Nasdaq up 0.3%

It’s hard to get a feel for the overall tone of the …

Morning

Vaguely flat, after a pause in the rally yesterday. Gold still going up, other commods likewise. Equities flat (though Nasdaq still hitting all time highs). Bonds flat, but given the risk-off feeling of the day, it feels like they should be on their way down. Wolf sees inflation, even …

item.description:
Morning

Risk off: bonds up (a teeny bit), equities off (quite a bit, but after a huge rally yesterday), commodities generally down, with the sole exception of natural gas.

item.title: Market Notes, 2nd July 2020
item.description:
Morning

Nearly everything up, a teeny bit. Dollar down, similarly. Dollar assets essentially flat. Independence Day holiday coming up. item.title: Market Notes, 1st July 2020
item.description:
Morning call

Well, it’s a new day, a new quarter and a new half year. Fairly incredibly, the SPX had the best quarter performance since 1998. Well, we know what happened in 2000. Asian equities up, European ones down. Odd, given that the police in Hong Kong are arresting …

item.description:
FDR:

There was a rather dull lecture by Gove over the weekend, the Ditchley Lecture. I read it, so you don’t have to. It’s long and a bit rambling. Bemoans hollowing out of the middle, and the resulting disaffection of those who used to support the left, the …

item.description:
ETF Buying

The Fed is doing it, but not in huge size. Various issuers are being identified on Twitter etc. as though their appearance on the list would be a buy signal. Similarly, a list of the ETFs, headed by $LQD, as you’d probably expect.

Things look a …

item.description:
Bubblicious

When the stock and bond market crash comes, and the politicians say “nobody could have seen this coming”, at least Lance Roberts and Jeremy Grantham will be able to say “we did!” And, actually, they are not the only ones.

item.description:
It’s too hot

I’m lethargic. My office is at 29C and humid. The markets are lethargic. At some point new homes in the UK will be fitted with A/C. Liquidity is terrible, even for $ES_F, the SP 500 mini future, which should be the most liquid equity …

item.description:

Wirecard reverberations.

item.description: Wolf Richer, who I’ve found particularly enlightening of late, has announced that he’s gone short of SPX I, Who Hates Shorting, Just Shorted the Entire Stock Market. Here’s Why . I wish him luck. It’s very hard to make money by shorting. You’d generally do a …

item.description:
Market Notes

The fall of currencies under the spell of stocks worries strategists is yet another article which points out that risk on/risk off now dominates all securities markets. Fed expansion pushes investors into risk on markets, and even in FX, traditionally a much bigger and liquid market than …

item.title: Market Notes, 18th June 2020
item.description:

WHEN DOES A STOCK ACT RIGHT?

Stocks, like individuals, have character and personality. Some are high-strung, nervous, and jumpy: others are forthright, direct, logical. One comes to know and respect individual securities. Their action is predictable under varying sets of conditions.
